Hmm,...I read his code to catch all Exceptions, and then the assert fails if it is not his expected one.

-------------- Original message -------------- 
*snip*
> I prefer:
> 
> try {
>    articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
>    fail("Expected NoObjectFoundException);
> } catch (Exception e) {
>    assertSame(e.getClass(), NoObjectFoundException.class);
>    // or whatever else seems appropriate (eg. testing getMessage() or
> other attribute)
> }

Is that assertSame really necessary or is it syntactic fluff much like
the assertTrue? After all if they weren't the same, the catch wouldn't
have caught it, right? About the only thing it could do for you might
be to catch unexpected subtypes.

Simon
